entry.title: Random Readings for the week of July 19, 2015
entry.summary:
Google’s Gorila - Some details on Google’s massively distributed architecture for deep reinforcement learning. A nice article explaining what it is all about can be found here.

Outlier Detection at Netflix - from the Netflix’s tech blog on how they automate the detection of servers operating in a degraded state using DBSCAN and Simulated Annealing.

Using logs to build a solid data infrastructure - Martin Kleppman, the author of the upcoming book Designing Data-Intensive Applications explains how thinking in terms of logs can help to build scalable data infrastructure. The book looks great too … if you have a Safari subscription, you can read it here.

Coupon Purchase Prediction - a new retailing domain focussed competition at Kaggle. From the competition’s description page - ‘Using past purchase and browsing behavior, this competition asks you to predict which coupons a customer will buy in a given period of time’.

entry.title: Random Readings for the week of July 12, 2015
entry.summary:
The Model Complexity Myth - if you construct your models carefully, you can fit models with more parameters than datapoints …

Automated learning method selection and tuning using Optunity , a free tool for hyperparameter tuning in the context of Machine Learning. Written in Python and has interfaces for Matlab, Java and Octave.

Introduction to Probability and Statistics - Spring 2014 - another probability course from MIT’s OCW. Haven’t finished with it yet but looks interesting.

Reading Group for PRML - Mastering PRML is considered a must for any serious Machine Learning practitioner… And it always helps to read it again (or for the first time if you haven’t already).
